series of annual internal reports. In 2007-08 alone, the MoD settled a tranche of 57 cases a further 20 were concluded between 2003 and 2010. Overall, 159 claims were made, with some rejected and others withdrawn, the FoI response said.It comes just weeks after the government admitted it had treated former royal navy radio operator Joe Ousalice “in a way that would not be acceptable today” when he was forced out of the senior service in 1993.Falklands War veteran Mr Ousalice, who is bisexual, was also stripped of a long service and good conduct medal when he was discharged. The award will now be returned to him, following court action that concluded earlier this month.Other former service members can apply for medals lost in similar circumstances to be reinstated.The MoD spokesman added: “Any iniduals who forfeited a medal in connection with an offence, for which they are able to obtain a disregard under the terms of the Protection of Freedoms Act 2012, will need to apply for the restoration of the medal under the terms of the policy being operated by the Cabinet Office.“Cases will be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“We accept our policy in respect of serving homosexuals in the military was wrong, discriminatory and unjust to the iniduals involved.”Wrecked German cruiser found a century after it was sunk by Royal NavyMr Tatchell said the number of people dismissed from the forces because of their sexual orientation “is likely to run into thousands given that the military witch-hunts continued unabated from the late 1940s until 1999”.“Some of those military personnel not only lost their job and income, but also their home, pension and friends,” he added. “Many found it very difficult to get new work.”Clare Collier, advocacy director at the Liberty campaign group, said: “Many people suffered horribly under officially sanctioned discrimination and persecution as a result of the ban on LGBT+ people in the armed forces.“The MoD has been far too slow to offer proper apologies and recompense for their suffering. Ministers should be doing all they can to put this right.”In a written answer to a parliamentary question in January, defence minister Tobias Ellwood said that “since the lifting of the ban on LGBT personnel serving in the military in the year 2000, the MoD has welcomed and supported all personnel, irrespective of sexual orientation, actively celebrating and supporting the ersity of all our personnel.”He added: “Support is available including through LGBT champions, senior LGBT role models, active LGBT networks and over 150 personnel trained by Stonewall as LGBT allies.”All three branches of the forces are ranked by Stonewall, a leading campaign group, as among its top 100 employers.Ministry of Defence&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Premium.Firms continued to freeze their spending plans, manufacturers were buffeted by stockpiling efforts and builders suffered amid a slowing housing marketBrexit uncertainty ensured 2019 was another difficult year for the economy, as the UK flirted with recession after two EU withdrawal deadline extensions kept firms and households in limbo.With a deepening downturn in the wider global economy compounding home-grown issues, activity in the UK limped to the year-end finish line amid signs that growth was stagnating across the major sectors.While Britain avoided a technical recession in the third quarter after a contraction the previous three months, there was little cheer as uncertainty over the Brexit outcome and then the December general election left the economy in stop-start mode all year.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFirms continued to freeze their spending plans, manufacturers were buffeted by stockpiling efforts ahead of the 31 March and 31 October deadlines and builders suffered amid a slowing housing market thanks to wavering buyer confidence.The year began with a bang, as stockpiling before the original spring Brexit cut-off pushed growth up Diwali celebrations in Trafalgar Square, LondonThis was double the out-turn for the end of 2018, though the boost proved short-lived as the manufacturing fillip unwound over the next three months to see the economy contract for the first time since 2012.Activity shrank by 0.2 per cent between April and June as the manufacturing and construction sectors both slumped.Firms that&nbspspent the first three months of the year stockpiling instead moved to use up their stores before building up new reserves.Signs that the economy continued to splutter over the summer sparked worries the UK could enter a recession – defined by two consecutive quarters of economic decline.These fears were allayed when the economy returned to growth in the third quarter with 0.3 per cent expansion – but the uncertainty ramped up towards the end of the year after Prime Minister Boris Johnson called a snap election.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailBritain may have avoided recession – but we shouldn’t be celebratingAdded to all&nbspthis was the volatile situation between the US and China as their trade war escalated over the year, which has compounded the global growth slowdown, with knock-on effects on the UK.Official figures showed Britain’s growth flatlined in October and sector surveys since then have painted an equally gloomy picture.The Bank of England cut its outlook for fourth-quarter growth to a paltry 0.1 per cent as the prospects for the economy began to look decidedly downbeat and left the door firmly open to an interest rate cut in its last decision of 2019.While rates were held at 0.75 per cent all year, two of the Bank’s policymakers have voted since November for a cut to 0.5 per cent.The solid Conservative Party win is seen as potentially offering a boost in the form of government spending, while also lifting the clouds of political uncertainty.But by far the biggest factor affecting growth is Brexit and trade deal prospects, which remain far from certain as Mr Johnson has signalled he will seek to pass legislation that could cause a cliff-edge Brexit at the end of 2020.George Brown at Investec said: “A no-deal Brexit could still manifest itself as soon as the end of next year, whereas a re-escalation in the US-China trade dispute cannot be ruled out.”Despite this caution, Investec still believes rates will be lifted to 1 per cent in mid-2021.Howard Archer, chief UK economic adviser to the EY Item Club, said the outlook for the economy in 2020 will once again see Brexit as the deciding factor and the Bank may need to take action if growth remains in the doldrums.And with inflation remaining well below the Bank’s 2 per cent target – at 1.5 per cent in November – there is room to do so if necessary.Mr Archer said: “If the UK economy fails to show clear signs of picking up in the early months of 2020, pressure will clearly mount on the Bank of England to trim interest rates to provide support.“Pressure for lower interest rates could also mount if the economy continues to be hampered by concerns over the UK’s longer-term relationship with the EU and what will happen at the end of 2020 when the transition arrangement will be due to end.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Premium.‘Sustained, dramatic, and consistently unexpected&nbspdecline’ in rates has driven property values sky-highSoaring house prices over the past four decades have been caused largely by low interest rates, not by a lack of supply of homes, research by the Bank of England has found.A paper by two economists at the bank found that falling real interest rates have been responsible for the majority of the rise in prices of homes.“Nearly all of the rise in average house prices relative to incomes can be seen as a result of a sustained, dramatic, and consistently unexpected, decline in real interest rates,” the researchers wrote.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThis leaves the UK exposed to significant falls in house prices when interest rates rise and mortgage debt becomes more expensive.Average house prices could plunge by one-fifth if there is an unexpected interest rate rise of 1 percentage point which is then is sustained over several years, the Bank of title: russia kremlin navalny opposition leader military service arctic
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘This is&nbspa kidnapping,’ says soldiers' rights activist. ‘Unfortunately, it’s part of a growing trend of lawless behaviour by the Ministry of Defence’Russian authorities mixed the traditional and the shocking this week with&nbspa crackdown on Kremlin foe Alexei Navalny and his allies.&nbspThe opposition leader was arrested following a raid at his Moscow offices shortly after noon on Thursday. Using power tools to gain entry, officers confiscated laptops and other electronic equipment. According to Mr Navalny, the raid was linked to&nbsphis refusal to comply with a court order and delete an investigation into prime minister Dmitry Medvedev from his YouTube site.&nbspThe arrest itself was not unusual: over the last calendar year, Mr Navalny has spent one in every eight days in police cells. But it followed the more extraordinary news that one of his employees had been seized at his home and dispatched to a remote military base in the Arctic.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesRuslan Shaveddinov, 23, was detained on Monday night at his home in Moscow. Colleagues only raised the alarm upon discovering the door of his&nbspapartment had been forced open. Mr Shaveddinov had not been able to contact either them or a lawyer: his mobile phone was mysteriously&nbspdisabled.&nbspBefore his own arrest three days later, Mr Navalny suggested that the order to arrest Mr Shaveddinov came from the very top.“It seems Putin put together the operation to isolate our Ruslan,” Mr&nbspNavalny wrote on Twitter. “His SIM card was blocked, the security service broke down his door and he was whisked away on several planes.”&nbspNew details on mass shooting reveal dark underbelly of Russian armyFor many hours, there was no news about Mr Shaveddinov’s whereabouts. The first clues came from social media channels with close links to the security services. These&nbsppublished footage showing the activist being led with his belongings into a minivan with a “VIP” sign. The snow on the roads –&nbspthe winter in European Russia is unseasonably warm –&nbspsuggested he was somewhere in the Russian north.&nbspEventually, on Tuesday, Mr Shaveddinov was declared found, 3,500 miles away at an air defence base in the Arctic archipelago of Novaya Zemlya.&nbspNovaya Zemlya is known for its severe, windswept climate the home of polar bears, ice and permafrost. It was also the location for tests of the largest atomic bomb&nbspin history in 1961. The tests happened at the north of the archipelago. The base where Mr Shaveddinov has been sent is at the southern tip, and specialises in Russia’s top-of-the-range S-300 and S-400 anti-aircraft systems.&nbspWhen it finally came round to admitting details, the Kremlin was unapologetic. The form of the conscription did not leave a shadow over the Russian army, spokesperson&nbspDmitry Peskov insisted.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailWhile forced conscription is unusual in Moscow, it is not the first time that authorities have used strong-arm tactics against the opposition. In 2007, for example, Oleg Kozlovsky, now a researcher for Amnesty, was seized and sent away for military service. He successfully appealed against the conscription, however, and was freed&nbsptwo and a half months later.&nbspMr Kozlovsky told The Independent that he had heard of several cases similar to his own, but suggested that the “outrageous” nature of this week’s operation –&nbspthe Arctic destination, timing and form of arrest – was designed to shock.&nbsp“Breaking down doors is what you do with dangerous criminals,” he said.One year’s military service is compulsory for all Russian males aged 18 to 28, but exemptions are possible. At the time of his forced conscription, Mr Shaveddinov had lost an appeal against the draft on medical grounds.&nbspValentina Melnikova, the head of the Russian Union of Committees of Soldiers' Mothers, was critical of the tactics used by Mr Shaveddinov and his lawyers. He should have taken precautions, she said –&nbspfor example by living elsewhere for a time. That said, authorities had “clearly” sidestepped due process in sending Mr Shaveddinov to the Arctic.&nbsp“The authorities did not do things by the book, which makes this a kidnapping,” she said. “Unfortunately, it’s part of a growing trend of lawless behaviour by the Ministry of Defence.”&nbspAccording to Ms Melnikova,&nbspa culture of violent bullying and criminal behaviour is also on the rise. In October, a Russian conscript killed eight of his fellow soldiers after apparently being subjected to bullying by his commanders. It was but the most shocking of dozens of such cases, she said.&nbspGiven his political&nbspstatus, however, Mr Shaveddinov will likely avoid such humiliation.“The commanders will do everything they can to avoid scandals … and to keep him away from the missiles,” his fellow activist Oleg&nbspKozlovsky suggested.“That said, I imagine Putin won’t be flying over the Arctic Ocean any time soon.”&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Israeli&nbspprime minister was bundled off stage in a campaign rally for his party’s primaries amid rocket fire from Gaza&nbspIsraeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared victory in a vote challenging his leadership, after TV stations predicted a landslide win for the Israeli leader.Mr Netanyahu, who has headed the right-wing Likud party for 14 years, appeared to have&nbspcrushed an internal rebellion led by veteran politician Gideon Saar during his party’s primary elections. The apparent victory means that Mr Netanyahu will lead Likud into March elections.Official results will be announced on Friday but partial results reported by Israeli TV stations showed Mr&nbspNetanyahu&nbspcapturing between 70 and 80 per cent of the vote – trouncing his challenger.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“A giant victory,” Mr Netanyahu tweeted, just over an hour after polls closed.“Thanks to the members of Likud for the trust, support and love,” he said. “God willing, I will lead Likud to a big victory in the coming elections.”The prime minister’s&nbspleadership has been shaken by corruption charges against him and a failure to form a government.Mr Netanyahu twice failed to build a ruling coalition after elections in April and September,&nbspleading to the unprecedented third vote this spring.He has also faced a backlash over continued escalations and heavy exchanges of fire between militants in Gaza and Israel’s security&nbspforces over the last year.As the prime minister campaigned in the southern city of Ashkelon on Wednesday, he was forced to flee the stage when a rocket fired from Gaza&nbspset off sirens.&nbspIsrael to be investigated for war crimes in Palestinian TerritoriesIt was the second time&nbsphe has been bundled off stage due to incoming&nbspfire – he was rushed to a rocket shelter&nbspin the nearby city of Ashdod in September.But despite the difficulties&nbspand the shadow of corruption indictment, the premier remains a popular figure within the right-wing party.​Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailHis rival Mr Saar, a former education and interior minister,&nbsphas garnered support from a handful of Likud backbenchers who have said it is time for fresh leadership.&nbspAs people headed to the polls, Mr Saar told reporters that Israel needed “a new path... to form a strong and stable&nbspgovernment, that will allow us to unite the people of Israel.”Government to stop public bodies boycotting Israel and other countriesIsrael urges Turkey to cut ties with Hamas Boris Johnson to pass law banning anti-Israel boycott, official saysIsrael to hold unprecedented third election in under a yearTrump says pro-Israel group will vote for him to protect their moneyMr Netanyahu,&nbspIsrael’s longest-serving prime minister,&nbsphas dismissed Mr Saar’s challenges portraying&nbsphim as inexperienced while talking up his own security credentials and diplomatic prowess.But&nbsphe has faced a tough challenge&nbspafter he was indicted on charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in three corruption cases, in which he is accused of trading legislative or regulatory favours in exchange for lavish gifts or favourable media coverage.He denies wrongdoing and has called the legal proceedings against him a political witch hunt. His supporters have tried to paint Mr Saar as part of the same conspiracy.He has also failed twice to build a ruling coalition.Mr Netanyahu’s main rival, former military chief Benny Gantz,&nbspwho heads up the centrist Blue and White Party,&nbspwas also unable to form a government.Both Netanyahu and Gantz said they wanted to create a unity government, but fought over Mr Netanyahu’s position as prime minister.Although Mr Saar is expected to lose the primaries, as Likud’s leader, he would likely have a better chance of creating a national unity government with Gantz’s Blue and White party after the March elections.Recent polls also show that with Saar as leader, Likud would make a more powerful bloc with its natural ultra-Orthodox and nationalist allies.Some 116,048 Likud members are eligible to vote in the party primary.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: the most marginalised children across the world what hope for 2020
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Paddy Dowling, The Independent’s humanitarian photojournalist, looks back at his pictures and stories from across the world this yearCreated with Sketch.In photos: Most marginalised children across the world Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.David, 13, arrived in Uganda in July 2016 fleeing the civil war that broke out in South Sudan. He arrived with his mother and father and his eight brothers and sisters after two days of walking. He recalls seeing many dead bodies lining the sides of the tracks that led to Uganda’s northern border. The family were fearful of abduction by rebel groups or becoming caught in crossfire between the government and militia groups. David enjoyed school immensely in South Sudan but said his school had closed due to conflict. He attends Alaba School at Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement. David dreams of a better life for his family.Sarah, 14, arrived to Kigeme refugee camp from DRC in 2012. Her parents, now unemployed in Rwanda, worked as rag traders. They made the decision to flee the fighting for the safety and relative calm of Rwanda. They were made to feel very welcome by the host community. Sarah is enrolled in class, three years behind where she should be, due to conflict, and she really enjoys her schooling. GS Gasaka school, run by Education Above All Foundation and UNHCR, is providing her the environment to allow her to dream one day of becoming an accountant so she can help her family live a better life.Nakato 19, was born and raised in Yumbe, Uganda. A graduate from Aruma High School, she has aspirations of becoming a journalist. She is actively involved in a movement called “Raise up and Talk” to help empower the younger generation to share their experiences and stories as a form of therapy, to help process the trauma from a life in conflict. Forestal, nine, is in second grade at Marescot School, Haiti. title: ian austin labour lefties public blame
story: I told them my cat would do a better job than Corbyn.Ten days since Labour’s drubbing and he still hasn’t been shown the door. He’s hanging on to stitch up the leadership for hard-left candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey.Some of his supporters set up a Twitter campaign called #JeremyWasRight!What planet are they on  They just suffered the biggest battering for almost a century.Let me spell it out for them. You were wrong.Wrong to block Brexit. Wrong to present a manesto costing billions. And wrong to ask Britain to vote for an unelectable old leftie.But none of the candidates to replace Corbyn seem to understand why they suffered such a crushing defeat.Keir Starmer praised Corbyn’s “radicalism” and said Labour should build on his disastrous approach.And let’s not forget he sat in Corbyn’s top team as decent MPs were driven out and the party was poisoned by racism and extremism.Emily Thornberry launched her campaign by suggesting Labour should have blocked the election. The rest of us thought they needed a leader the country could vote for.Along with Rebecca Long-Bailey and David Lammy, she nominated Corbyn for the leadership — and that should rule all of them out of replacing him.There’s another long list of candidates for deputy leader. The most ridiculous has to be Richard Burgon.The Leeds MP said: “The mistake we made was being persuaded that people did not quite want to get Brexit done as their top priority.”Can someone provide a translation Labour lefties are blaming anyone but themselves. title: labour unelectable leaders red len
story: Meddling Red Len McCluskey is already trying to stitch up the contest to replace Jeremy Corbyn by hand-picking a candidate from the same discredited mould.The Unite union leader has held secret meetings to plot the coronation of Corbyn devotee Rebecca Long-Bailey, who was a key part of Labour’s election disaster.The delusion seems to be that this political lightweight, dubbed Wrong-Daily by critics, can somehow sell Corbyn’s fantasy agenda because she is a fresh voice from the North.But the reality is that voters saw through Jezza’s disastrous s-style socialism and won’t be fooled regardless of who’s peddling it.In a sane world, Labour would work out where it should be going before picking a leader.But its union paymaster pulls the strings, and Red Len and his Momentum mates want a puppet to carry on spouting the same nonsense that just delivered Labour’s worst defeat since .At some point this once-proud party must learn the lessons of the election and move back towards the middle ground.But that will only happenit shakes off the malign influence of union bosses who wield far too much power behind the scenes.While Red Len and his cronies set the agenda, Labour will be saddled with unelectable leaders for years to come.TAKE a Christmas bow!Your generosity has helped sick children across Britain.Thanks to the thousands of pounds Sun on Sunday readers donated to our Quids for Kids campaign, we were able to hand out Christmas presents to brave youngsters in hospitals across the country.The beaming smiles on the faces of these children as Santa made his surprise visit to their bedsides has been a joy for their families and friends.We knew you were a big-hearted bunch. title: struggling family universal credit sandwiches christmas dinner
story: Neil Campbell and Jo Holbrook-Morris, who both claim Universal Credit are living on just £ a week.The parents-of-two have said that financial pressures mean they wont be able to have a proper Christmas dinner this year.The family has put all its savings into a community farm project on Nunsthorpe Estate, Grimsby.But a hold up in a planning application to expand their farm has meant the couple have had to use their own money to keep the business up and running.In order to ensure their kids Olivia,  and Monty, , have gts on Christmas day, the family are preparing for a budget festive season without turkey or pigs in blankets.With  animals to feed, including donkeys, sheep, pigs, goats and chickens, as well as bills to pay, the family says it will be left eating sandwiches on Christmas day.Neil said: At the moment we are really struggling, we have put everything that we had into setting up the farm, but due to the delays that we have had with planning, we have been forced onto Universal Credit.The thing is, the community have really rallied around the farm and embraced it as their own, so we feel that we have to keep things going for them, in the hope that some day we can turn things around.Because we were initially told that our planning application would take just eight weeks, we were given assurances that we could invest in the farm, and then once we did, the application was delayed indefinitely, putting us where we are at the moment.I just hope that we can get this sorted soon, so that we can get the Nunnys Farm properly up and running.Jo said that while they have made sure that their kids have presents this Christmas, she and Neil will be going without anything, as they do not have the funds.The family has been claiming Universal Credit since June.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Jo said: Now we know what it is like to live on nothing, we have got used to going without.We have sold everything that we can possibly sell to keep ourselves going, but we just dont know how long we can last like this.At the minute, it looks like we will just be having sandwiches this Christmas, because we cant afford anything  after making sure that our kids have presents and are well cared for.This comes as another young family were forced into debt and had to rely on handouts after having a five-week wait to receive Universal Credit.A spokesperson for North East Lincolnshire Council said: We are in contact with Centre and have met a number of times to explain that we need to make up for the loss of the sports pitch.We have explained this position several times and what we’re doing to try and resolve it.The Council is supportive of the farm, and as landlord would be agreeable to the proposal.However, any sub-lease or change of use is subject to the necessary permissions and whilst we are doing our utmost to resolve the situation, there is a process to follow when someone wants to change the use of a sports field.We are working with Sport England to try to resolve this to allow their objection to the plans to be lted.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. Universal Credit claimants could have Christmas benefits slashed  bosses pay wages early this month.Meanwhile, a five-week wait for Universal credit payouts has pushed a young family into debt and forced them to rely on handouts.And with changes coming into force in  around how Universal Credit works - find out how they will affect your payments.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says football eradicate racism
story: Le bans for offenders. Close the stadium for a match — or at the very least the stand where the abuse came from.Racism at grounds was far worse in the past. But it has spiked again and can be wiped out with severe enough deterrents.We don’t buy, though, that these morons are emboldened by politicians.The Left seeks to blame Boris Johnson for everything.So they pretend his use of words like “piccaninnies”, in a  satirical attack on white leaders posing as colonial masters, was motivated by racism.No one who knows Boris thinks that of him.No one but the racists themselves are to blame for the Spurs outrage.Our leagues must stop wringing their hands and take forceful action.THE defiance of American death-crash driver Anne Sacoolas is outrageous.She accepts that she killed teenager Harry Dunn while driving on the wrong side of the road in the UK. But her lawyer says a prosecution and potential jail term is “not a proportionate response”.Britain is not a banana republic.Our justice system is as advanced as America’s. It is for our courts, not a suspect or her lawyer, to decide what is proportionate.Accidents can have consequences.Mrs Sacoolas will not want to leave her kids.Neither should she want them living with the knowledge their mum killed a young man and fled into hiding.Our Government must pursue extradition and the US must grant it — as we doubtless would were the roles reversed.ED Miliband won’t need long to diagnose the cause of four Labour election defeats in a row.He was behind three of them.Brown, the hapless oaf, lost in .Miliband then took the party to the left, gting the Tories their  winAnd Ed was just getting started.He sold party memberships for £ and the hard-Left piled in, made the toxic fool Corbyn leader and two more defeats followed.Who would now bet against a fth, given the new leadership candidates The latest, Islington snob Emily Thornberry, has a distaste for working-class people which is mutual — as White Van Man Dan Ware makes clear today.And in branding our PM — newly elected by million voters — a “feckless, lying charlatan”, Thornberry promises five more years of the same juvenile abuse putting millions off Labour.Not learning much, are they THREE years of furious political ision.Wasn’t it fantastic when it stopped To all Sun readers — Left or Right, Leavers or Remainers — have a fabulous Christmas! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queens speech heal nation
story: The Queen — with her beloved husband in hospital — faced the cameras on Sunday with her usual stf upper lip as she attended a carol service at Sandringham.She was doing what she does best, getting on with things quietly but resolutely when it gets tough.And make no mistake, this year has been a second annus horribilis for the monarch.A year that began with the Duke of Edinburgh’s involvement in a car crash that left a motorist injured, ended with him being rushed to hospital by helicopter due to a pre-existing condition.She has also had to endure her favourite son Prince Andrew becoming so entwined in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal that it was in danger of damaging the monarchy itself.Then Prince Harry confirmed reports that he and Prince William had fallen out.One of the joys that Christmas brings for the Queen is it bringing the whole family together. But sadly the newest member, ArchieHarrison Mountbatten-Windsor, won’t be there.He will be with his parents Harry and Meghan somewhere in Canada, celebrating away from the royals.That’s a real shame, because with his upbeat presence Harry would have got the Queen laughing over the turkey.I watched the boys grow up, and you couldn’t then get a cigarette paper between them.It will sadden the Queen that Harry is not there and that he doesn’t seem to get on with his brother any more.As a nation, we have huge rts to heal over Brexit. In her traditional Christmas Day speech the Queen will ask the country to come together and heal the wounds.I’m sure one of her priorities in the New Year will not only be to unite the country, but to bring together her beloved grandsons and their wives.But it’s the Epstein outrage that did most to threaten the House of Windsor this year.The Queen must have been horried to watch the car- crash interview Andrew gave to the BBC.With his arrogance and lack of preparation, Andrew — a Falklands War hero — turned what he hoped could have been his redemption into a nightmare.The Queen, with the advice of the Prince of Wales, acted swtly. Andrew was stripped of his royal duties. The institution has to be protected at all times.Of course, it would have been hard for the Queen to do all this, but she did it with calm and with grace, the hallmarks our redoubtable, -year-old monarch.We should not forget this. This remarkable woman continues to serve us when many would have crumbled.You will not hear the slightest grumble from our Queen.Thank heavens for that.While it seems the royals can do no right, the Queen carries on as normal. She rides her Fell pony most weekends and watches the racing on TV and gets excited when she picks a winner.Her family looks to her at times of ision and uncertainty — and so does the nation.The country is polarised over Brexit and one of the things the Queen wants to see is the isions healed and for people to come together in the New Year.Since he retired, the Duke of Edinburgh has lived in Sandringham, so the Queen is rattling around in her apartments with just servants to talk to. She can’t confide in them like she can the Duke. The scandal that has engulfed Prince Andrew will have saddened her so much. But she won’t abandon her son. She loves him.All families face rts and scandals at one time or another. The Windsors are no dferent. Their story is all about continuity, both for the nation and the Royal Family.So the Queen will have loved the recently released new photographs of herself with the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and Prince George preparing a Christmas pudding for charity.It was a royal flush, the Monarch with three generations of heirs. I will be at Sandringham at am tomorrow to photograph theQueen and her family as they arrive at St Mary Magdalene Church.She will pray for the strength to carry on through what are likely to be bumpy roads ahead.And bumps there will be. The Andrew scandal is far from over and  could be a pivotal year for the Duke, who has yet to face the FBI.So when you watch the Queen give her Christmas message tomorrow afternoon, spare a thought for someone who has served this country so dutully and for so long.An amazing woman of true decency and honour.We remain lucky to have her.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle if i was prime minister
story: And dates. Actually, does anyone still eat dates  Lined up in their narrow little box like cockroaches waiting for the resurrection.Awful bloody things. Yet I still buy a box every Christmas and never eat them.And then tonight. Turkey curry  Turkey salad or turkey sandwiches  Turkey in the basket with sautéed turkey strips in a turkey sauce Why do we do it  Spunk our entire earnings on a day of epic indulgence. I bet the kids are back playing with stuff they DIDN’T get for Christmas by now.And as for the dog . . . well we didn’t want her to feel left out. So we bought her a special Gourmet Dog Christmas Dinner made of . . . yes, turkey. And goose.And our reward for this kindness is to have her lying at our feet all day farting like a wizard.The clouds of gas are so toxic there are flies and spiders dropping dead within ten feet of the animal.Still, it’s what Jesus would have wanted, I suppose.I hope you had a great day and are taking it easy right now. And to those of you working, respect.I quite like working over Christmas Day and Boxing Day. It makes me feel virtuous, which is a rare occurrence.Anyway, there is good reason for cheer this Yuletide. The thick-as-mince rapper Stormzy may have said: “F*** Boris.”But, rather wonderfully, the British people turned out in huge numbers to say, “F*** Stormzy” and: “F*** Magic Grandpa.”It now looks like Brexit will get done and we have a government which MUST respect the wishes of all those new working-class people who voted for it.Boris is doing very well so far. It was a decent Queen’s Speech. And I like the idea his adviser Dominic Cummings has of building new nuclear power plants in the North of England.Lots of well-paid jobs and clean energy. I love nukes, me.But there were a few things missing from Boris’s first programme for government — so I thought I’d help him out.What follows is a list of the stuff I’d like the Government to do.Some of them, as you will see, are very specic to me and might not find accord nationally.It’s a wish list for what I’d do , in some terrible vision of hell, I was ever elected Prime Minister . . . Reduce immigration. I mean really reduce it. To something like nine people per year. I get to choose who the nine are. Most of them will be from Hong Kong. Don’t underestimate the strength of feeling against unlimited immigration, BoJo. Andyou reduce immigration you won’t need to pave over half of our remaining countryside to build new houses. Our urgent need for housing is a consequence of a population expanding because of immigration. Stop sending children to the controversial Tavistock Clinic in London for gender realignment treatment. If people wish to transition, let them wait until they are  . In fact, let’s get rid of all the identity politics stuff. It’s isive and fatuous. We’re all in this together and it doesn’t matterwe’re gay or straight, white or black, Muslim or Christian, Jew or Hindu. Treat everybody equally. And end the hierarchy of whingeing victimhoods. Ban all factory farming. Immediately. Outlaw cats. Scrap the high-speed HS line and spend the money on faster links between the North West of England and the North East. Or spend it all on a TeessideService to replace the crap antiquated trains we have now. Remember how Teesside voted in the election, Boris  Close the polytechnics in which kids who are not very academic pay more than £, to get a worthless degree in gender studies or something. Reduce the number of people going to university by  per cent. Introduce apprenticeships and technical colleges. And scrap tuition fees. Insist that university staff must represent a ersity of opinion. All universities which “no ” speakers to be punished financially. End the BBC licence fee. Insist that cyclists always use cycle lanes where they have been provided. Reduce the number of buses in London by  per cent in off-peak times. Make it illegal for lorries to overtake on two-lane dual carriageways and motorways. Make smoking legal in pubs that I go to. And other pubs,you like. Recognise Jerusalem as being the capital of Israel and move our embassy there. Outlaw the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement for its horrible anti-Semitism. Stop meddling in Middle Eastern politics. Stop invading Muslim countries, or bombing them. Accept that they may not want to live in democracies, or believe what the rest of us believe. Keep a bit of a closer eye on the Chinese state. Increase our military strength to three per cent of GDP. Force Heinz to reintroduce Toast Toppers and Cadbury to reintroduce the Aztec bar. Divert more money from the Premier League to grass-roots football development and also to clubs below the top ision. Especially Millwall, natch. Drop the notion that people who allege that they have been raped MUST be believed. Allow the police to use common sense and discretion. Scrap all elected Police Commissioners and end the politicisation of our police force. Encourage the Old Bill to investigate crimes that genuinely hurt people — like burglaries, assaults and robberies — rather than supposed “hate crimes”. End the badger cull. Now. Make it legal to scratch or deface cars which have a “baby on board” sign in their windows. Recognise that while our country must afford tolerance to all believers in all religions, the United Kingdom is by tradition a Christian country and that Christian values should be especially respected. Arrest elderly people who take too long at cashpoints. Maybe take their cards off them.  Make the former Speaker John Bercow do I’m A Celebrity . . . Get Me Out Of Here! along with some real low-rent nano-slebs, such as that Lauren Goodger woman and maybe Joey Essex. End all ersity training, everywhere. Ban restaurants from serving sourdough bread, or at least insist they provide an alternative to people who can’t stand the stuff. Invest a few quid in the north of England. Transfer some of the wealth from London to the magnicent towns and cities which once led our industrial revolution. Especially Middlesbrough. Put Extinction Rebellion protesters in a small cage with some hungry wolverines.That should do for now. Sort that stuff out by the end of February and maybe I’ll begin to trust the Tories . . .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jewellery shop burglary hero owner
story: Phil Sylvester, , sprang into action as he saw the masked would-be thief storming towards his store - immediately trying to block the door.In dramatic scenes, the jewellery store owner slipped and fell as he tried to close the shopfront, but determinedly kept kicking the door to stop the robber from getting in before smoke from a security system filled the shop.Terrying footage shows Mr Sylvester manage to stop the masked man from entering the Kenilworth family business, with the thief forced to flee.Speaking to the Sun Online, the -year-old said he knew something was wrong as soon as he saw the man jump off the waiting motorbike and run into Sylvesters the Jewellers about pm on Christmas Eve.He said: I was walking towards the door and a motorbike pulled up - I knew straight away it wasnt going to be good.He just ran in and I didnt want to let him in.Despite being left on the floor, Mr Sylvester can be seen kicking repeatedly as the surprised burglar tries to grab valuables in a confrontation that lasted only  seconds - while a man appearing to be armed with a machete waited outside.Mr Sylvester said: He was saying shooter, Ive got a shooter.He probably had watched too many episodes of The Sweeney.The term shooter is an old East End slang term often used in the s British television police drama.During the chaos, a large glass cabinet fell to the ground at the store, which has been run by Mr Sylvesters family since .Mr Sylvester added: I just kept slamming the door with my legs as he was yelling get down.I know I hurt him - title: brave boxing day swimmers freezing waters across britain
story: Donning Santa hats, elf costumes and the odd bikini, scores of brave swimmers didnt give a toss about hypothermia as they waded through waves to raise cash for charities.On its Facebook page, Whitby District Lions Club had challenged locals: Are you crazy or brave enough to run into the North Sea on Boxing Day for charity Fancy dress is a must, for many dippers, with prizes available for the best!Its certainly a unique and memorable experience that will raise lots of money for local charities.And in Liverpool, the Open Water Swimming Club urged people to clear out out the excesses of the night before.Locals swam theof the Salthouse Dock and enjoyed a dip into the dock off the pontoon.Unfortunately, the annual Boxing Day swim in the sea at both Sidmouth and Seaton along the East Devon coast were called off after strong gusts of wind battered the region overnight.But at Seaburn in Sunderland, more than  hardy souls clad in fancy dress rushed into the freezing sea for the th annual dip organised by the citys Lions Club.Onlookers witnessed festive scenes of a Santa Claus and turkey running into the rough sea to raise money for their chosen charities.Among the other quirky costumes to be seen were mermaids, lobsters, whoopee cushions, cakes and a group of flapper girls all battling the bitter wind this morning.Jim Nicol, , treasurer of Sunderland Lions Club, said: They are overcoming the cold because they care about what they are doing and what they are supporting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu chief brexit love letter
story: Frans Timmermans said Britain has inflicted unnecessary damage on itself and warns more will follow in his soppy letter.He said the UKs decision to leave breaks my heart, but admitted the British people had always been in two minds about the EU.The Dutch nationals warning comes as the UK is due to leave the European Union on January .MPs passed Prime Minister Boris Johnsons Brexit deal on December , just eight days after the Conservative Party won a landslide majority in the general election.That date will start the clock running down to the end of the transition period during which London and Brussels will try to broker a future relationship including a trade deal.In the letter, Mr Timmermans spoke about when he attended a British International School in Rome and fell in love with the UK before saying he wished the UK didnt force the issue.He said he now feels like a spurned old lover over the split.The Dutch national wrote in : Was it necessary to force the issue  Not at all. But you did.Truth be told, I felt deeply hurt when you decided to leave. Three years later I am just sad that a member of our family wants to sever our ties.But at the same time I find comfort in the thought that family ties can never really be severed. We’re not going away and you will always be welcome to come back.A number of politicians have reacted to the love letter.Former Green Party leader Natalie Bennett, a new House of Lords peer, said the letter was Something to remember. And thank you.Andrew Adonis, Labour peer and ex-Transport Secretary, tweeted about the UKs : Just a matter of time.Paul Oakley, the former UKIP general secretary, wrote: Yuck. title: royal fan wheelchair delight princess charlotte hug
story: Gemma Clark, , has cerebral palsy and her mum has spoken about how her daughter has battled the debilitating brain condition all her le.Four-year-old Charlotte and older brother George, six, joined the Queen at the Royal Familys traditional Christmas Day church service for the first time.Gemma said that the young royal’s eyes were drawn towards the flamingo – called Felicity – before entering St Mary Magdalene church.Afterwards she headed straight for Gemma, who has suffered from cerebral palsy from when she was  months old.Gemma, from Long Sutton in Lincolnshire, told the Daily Mail: “Felicity was a th birthday present from my older sister, Fran, and she goes everywhere with me. Shes like my lucky mascot.“But Charlotte kept looking at Felicity and I thought: ‘I wonderthe Princess would like her ’“So when she came over with Prince George and their parents after the service, I asked her: ‘Would you like Felicity ’“Her face lit up and she said: ‘Yes please.’ I told Charlotte: ‘You dont have to call her Felicityyou dont want to you can call her whatever you want’.“Then both she and George gave me a hug and I was on cloud nine. They were so sweet and it is a moment I will remember for ever as being special. The atmosphere was just awesome.”Gemma - the youngest of three daughters - became seriously ill with gastroenteritis when she was a toddler.She spent four weeks in hospital, semi-comatose  but never fully recovered after doctors discovered severe dehydration and lasting brain damage, affecting her speech, balance and ability to walk.He mum Pam, , said: “Despite everything, Gemma is a happy young woman. She has just got on with le and taken everything in her stride.After the service at St Mary Magdalene Church, Princess Charlotte was spotted mingling with members of the public and spreading some festive joy.Charlotte, who was accompanied by mum Kate, was also handed a gt box by a well-wisher while another well-wisher presented Charlotte with a home-made doll.It comes after Prince William and Kate released a new photograph showing the duke kissing his youngest son, Louis, alongside George and Charlotte.The picture was posted by Kensington Palace on Twitter with the message: Merry Christmas to all our followers!The -year-old Queen, wearing a red coat and hat, attended the service with the Duchess of Cornwall.The Duke of Edinburgh, , who was discharged from hospital on Christmas Eve, was at Sandringham but did not attend church.He had spent four nights at the King Edward VII Hospital in London to receive treatment for a pre-existing condition.Philip, who retired from public duties in , did not attend last years church service either despite being in good health at the time.[ boxout]Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new year resolutions green eco friendly
story: Three-quarters more of us are concerned about the environment than we were in , according to a Sun survey — so many will be considering how to cause less pollution and harmful emissions.Here, I reveal how we can cause less waste, less pollution — and save money at the same time. How low-carbon can you go  Reduce meat and dairy consumption, as beef and sheep livestock have a high carbon footprint. If you’re not ready to go completely without, try Meat Free Mondays Grow your own: You don’t need a big garden. Salad leaves, chilli and herbs are just a few of the things that grow well in containers. It’s a low-cost way of reducing your reliance on super-market fruit and vegetables. Switch off when idle: Leaving TVs, games consoles, the washing machine and microwave on standby eats energy. Some appliances draw energy even when they are not being used and phone chargers are among the worst culprits. “Vampire power” costs each house up to £ a year, according to the Energy Saving Trust. Use energy-saving lightbulbs: LED bulbs can last up to , hours, while some newer models are good for double that. As they use far less energy, you will quickly see impressive savings on your energy bill each month. Which  magazine puts the annual cost of running an LED lightbulb at £., compared to £. for a CFLtype and £. for halogen. Over the course of an LED bulb’s very long letime, it can save you around £. Be a careful cook: Only use as much water as you need and cover your pans so you save energy. Overfilling your kettle is a waste of electricity so only boil as much as you need. Lose the plastic packaging: This wrapping is energy-intensive in its production and causes serious damage to habitats. Choose items that are light on packaging, and refill as much as possible. There is no reason to buy tomatoes on a plastic tray which is also wrapped in plastic. A loose tomato tastes just as good. Find out more about the supermarkets’ war against plastic. Go low: Set the washing machine at C or even C. Doing the laundry at C instead of C can be one third cheaper on energy. For lightly soiled clothes, try C. And make sure that your machine is full. Get free water-saving devices: Moving water around the country and treating it requires huge amounts of energy, so get in touch with your water company to find out what gadgets you can get for free, such as low-flow shower heads which use less water. Make your home cosy: Draught-proof your doors and windows, install secondary-film glazing, top up your loft insulation to cm and get your boiler serviced. Accord-ing to the Energy Saving Trust, loft insulation for a semi-detached house will cost around £, with £ savings a year, while insulating a mid-terrace house will cost around £ and save £ a year. Turn down radiators in rooms you are not using: You don’t need to heat a room you’re not in, so use radiator controls to adjust temperature. Slow down on fast fashion: We buy more and more clothes each year. So choose vintage items, rent something for those special occasions and don’t forget charity shops. Oxfam has a great online shop. For outfit rentals, try websites like byrotation, hirestreetuk and mywardrobehq. If you do really want to buy new clothes, look out for certications of sustain-ability. Use the Good On You app to find out which shops are reducing their impact on the environment. Watch super-market air miles: Potatoes do not rack up air miles like imported rice. Likewise, dairy has a high carbon footprint, so swap a latte for a regular coffee. Look for the Red Tractor symbol on food supplied by British farmers. Buy strawberries, for example, from Norfolk, not Morocco.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teen suspect tessa majors released
story: The -year-old had been arrested hours earlier on Thursday and was one of three youths police believe were involved in the stabbing of Tessa Majors, , on December , in a case that has shocked the city.Tessa was stabbed while walking in the park just before pm, two days before the start of final exams at Barnard, an all-womens school that is part of the Ivy League Columbia University.The aspiring journalist staggered up a flight of stairs to street level and collapsed in what police are called a robbery gone wrong.After being found unconscious around  minutes later, she was taken to Mount Sinai St. Lukes Hospital, New York, where she died.On Thursday, Chief of Detectives Rodney Harrison tweeted that finding the suspect “was a signicant development in the investigative process,” but that the youth had since been released to the custody of his lawyers. Harrison didn’t say why the boy was released.A police spokesman declined to provide details, saying “the investigation remains active and ongoing.”A spokesman for Neighborhood Defender Service confirmed that the organization is providing the boy with legal representation but declined to comment further.The case has become embroiled in controversy after the head of the NYPD sergeants’ union Ed Mullins claimed Tessa was in the park buying weed on the night she was killed.Mullins made the comments while discussing NYC crime rates on John Catsimatidis radio show, The Cats Roundtable.But Tessas family and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio accused the union boss of blaming Tessa for her own death.Her family told NBC: The remarks by Sergeants Benevolent Association president Ed Mullins we find deeply inappropriate.They intentionally or unintentionally direct blame onto Tess, a young woman, for her own murder.He later said his words had been twisted by the Mayor and apologized to Tessa’s family.Some city leaders have urged police to use caution in investigating Majors’ death to avoid repeating mistakes made with the Central Park Five — a group of five black and Hispanic teens wrongfully convicted of a  rape.Harrison said in a tweet that the youth taken into custody Thursday had lawyers present “for the entire investigative process.”At a press conference last week, he said the youths previously questioned in the Majors case had s present and were told of their right to a lawyer.The Legal Aid Society, which represents the first arrested youth, said detectives should have waited until he had a lawyer before questioning him.In the wake of Majors’ death, Barnard and Columbia faculty have reported receiving “abhorrent and viciously racist” robocall messages from a white supremacist organization, and a Connecticut man was arrested after police say he posted online that he was going to kill the suspected stabber.Majors played in a rock band, sported green hair and had told an editor from a newspaper internship in high school that she planned to take journalism classes in college.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu luvvies sobibng brits understand democracy
story: In , Ukip won the European elections. In , David Cameron — pledging a referendum — thrashed Ed Miliband in the election. In , Leave hoovered up .million more votes than Remain.In , the two main parties — both promising to respect the result — won a whopping  per cent of the vote.In , the Brexit Party nailed the European elections. And again this year Boris Johnson’s Conservatives wiped the floor with the “People’s Vote” gang.The mandate to Get Brexit Done could hardly be clearer.But still the unelected EU bureaucrats don’t get it. In a cringeworthy “love letter” published in the , a mind-bogglingly arrogant official tells readers that both Britain and Europe are “hurting” because of Brexit, and he would “welcome” us back.Well, thanks Frans Timmermans. But no thanks.European luvvies might be sobbing this holiday season, but we Brits understand the meaning of democracy. And most of us are downright excited about the prospect of independence.Roll on January .SHODDY British buses should shame our politicians.City centric parliament loves to bleat on about railways.Should they be nationalised  Is HS going to be scaled back  Will Crossrail for the North see the light of day So we’re thrilled that bus minister Baroness Vere is taking the problem in hand. A pioneering government project will see routes, timetables and prices joined up in the new year.It’s another sign that this government is serious about earning the trust of small town voters who’ve been treated like second-class citizens for far too long.REPORTS that Prince Charles would like to slim down the Royal Family suggests he’s got his head screwed on.Wills, Kate and their lovely children are the future of the Windsors. The Queen and Prince Philip have served this country with unwavering commitment for seven decades.They should feel confident handing over duties to younger members of The Firm without fretting about controversies whipped up by Andrew or Harry.Royal extras have always been more trouble than they’re worth. It’s time to concentrate on the key players.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner who fell and broke his arm was left to lie in the road in heavy rain for for almost two hours before an ambulance arrived. Witnesses rushed to the aid of -year-old Michael Foy and called him an ambulance after he fell in a street in Wolstanton, Stoke-on-Trent.A non-emergency ambulance was flagged down around half-an-hour later but staff were told not to move him, StrokeonTrent Live reports.An ambulance to take him to hospital finally arrived at .pm - almost two hours after the first call was made at .pm. Mr Foy was treated for a broken arm at Royal Stoke University Hospital. He also sustained grazes to his knee, elbow, leg and shoulder. Now the pensioner - who was categorised as a category three patient - is calling for the system to be changed so the elderly are not left lying in a road for so long. A category three means it is aposurgent but not le threateningapos and promises a response within  minutes. Mr Foy said: “When the ambulance arrived, the paramedic said, ‘I am so sorry we were so long but you are category three’. I do not really class myself as vulnerable but I should be. If it had been anyone  it could have cost them their lives. A -year-old should not be category three when he is lying in the road in the rain.  “It is a disgrace. It is not down to the people. It is the system. They need more ambulances on duty at this time of the year. “It was my own fault that I fell but I should not have had to wait so long. They should have come and checked me over. He added: “I do not want it to happen to anyone . I do not want to see anyone die as a result of the system being flawed.” While he waited, kind strangers tried to make him as comfortable as possible.  “A van driver made me a pillow and covered me with his jacket. He blocked the road off because I was in the road, he said. “I was walking my dog Millie when my ankle went over and I fell forward. I tried to save myself but could not and collapsed in the street. My feet were in the gutter and my head was in the road. I literally could not get up. I was in excruciating pain. The dog had run off. “A woman stopped with me until the end, in the wind and rain. My Foyaposs arm is now in a sling following the fall on December .

Karina Chikitova, who clung on to her loyal puppy, fought to stay alive in a forest full of brown bears and wolves. The promising ballerina celebrates her th birthday on Boxing Day and has already won the Mini Miss Yakutia contest. In August  she was found after a dozen days and nights lost in the remote taiga, sleeping on a bed of long grass and eating wild berries to stay alive. Karina had followed her father into the woods but he had no idea she was trailing him. Then just four years old, she cuddled her mongrel puppy Naida for warmth in the shivering cold before the dog found its way home to a remote village, urging rescuers not to give up, and to go and find the little girl. Karina’s ordeal was seen as so remarkable that a statue was erected of her and the dog in regional capital Yakutsk. A popular children’s book was also written about her, and her fame as a Mowgli seems to have led this remote village girl to amazing new opportunities. Karina was “excited” after she easily won the Mini Miss contest in a social media poll, making her a young ambassador for Yakutia, Russia’s diamond region, the coldest inhabited place in the world. She is seen as a promising ballerina, already studying full time in Yakutsk, some  miles from her home. Now she has been invited in  to Moscow to meet leading ballet stars including world famous dancer Nikolay Tsiskaridze, now rector of the world famous Vaganova Academy. “I want to become a ballerina and dance Swan Lake,” she said. “I have also learned how to play the jaw harp and piano.”  Bi-lingual Karina is doing well at school, too, where she has a talent for maths, and is learning English to add to her fluent Yakut and Russian. Herin Yakutsk, Albina Cherepanova, , said: “She may become a ballet dancer.” Globally-renowned fashion designer Irina Krutikova promised Karina a fur coat to keep warm in her region where temperatures plunge in winter to minus °C. When she was found her rescuer Artyom Borisov said: “She was sitting deep in deergrass, completely silent.  “I didn’t actually notice her. She saw me and stretched her arms forward. I picked her up, she was so tiny, so light, like fluff. She didn’t have shoes on. Her face, legs and arms were bitten to blood . “She was dead scared. Musician Elina Valiyeva, , was found by her boyfriend in the bathroom of a vacation rental flat in the Hungarian capital.
